text: Palæontology or paleontology is the study of fossils of living things, and their phylogeny (evolutionary relationships).Prothero, Donald R. 2007. Evolution: what the fossils say and why it matters. Columbia University Press, New York. It depends on basic sciences such as zoology, botany and historical geology. The term palaeobiology implies that the study will include the palaeoecology of the groups in question. In palaeozoology, the evolution of those animal phyla with fossil records are studied. In palaeobotany, fossil plants are studied. In historical geology the formation, sequence and dating of rock strata give information about past environments. A fossil is any kind of life that is more than ten thousand years old and preserved in any form that we can study today.Levin, Harold L. 2005. The Earth through time. 8th ed, Wiley, N.Y. Chapter 4: The fossil record. The fossil record is always incomplete, and later discoveries may extend the known survival of a group. See Lazarus taxon. Some palaeontologists study fossils of microorganisms, living things that are too small to see without a microscope, while other palaeontologists study fossils of giant dinosaurs. *Vertebrate palaeontology: the palaeontology of vertebrate animals *Invertebrate palaeontology: the palaeontology of invertebrate animals == Related pages == * Lagerstätte * Paleoanthropology * Palaeoclimatology == References == Category:Evolutionary biology Category:Earth sciences
